{"post_stream":{"posts":[{"id":3530830,"name":"Henry","username":"HawkbotsMentor","avatar_template":"/letter_avatar_proxy/v4/letter/h/d9b06d/{size}.png","created_at":"2025-02-18T00:48:18.995Z","cooked":"

Hey all,

We have done our best to get YAGSL working, but we’ve failed. Put about 150 hours into it the last month and a half. Read the documentation probably 15 times, completed the flow chart and eight steps, tuned PID, checked our conversion factors and encoder offsets a thousand times, re-loctite’d the magnets, and we still just can’t get it to work. Wheels spin out of control; they spin in different directions; AdvantageScope shows a wide variance between projected and actual angle; sometimes just 1 wheel spins…we’ve started new projects about 5 times, followed YouTube tutorials, and still just can’t do it alone. We’re dead in the water, and need expert assistance!

Can someone please send us a YAGSL template they’ve gotten to actually work? We know how to change all the properties and all that…just need to know if it’s our hardware.

Thank you ahead of time!!!

","post_number":1,"post_type":1,"posts_count":16,"updated_at":"2025-02-18T00:48:18.995Z","reply_count":0,"reply_to_post_number":null,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":19,"reads":107,"readers_count":106,"score":116.4,"yours":false,"topic_id":492104,"topic_slug":"in-need-of-working-yagsl-swerve-code","display_username":"Henry","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":null,"bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":68869,"hidden":false,"trust_level":1,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"post_url":"/t/in-need-of-working-yagsl-swerve-code/492104/1","custom_user_title":null,"reactions":[],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":0,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null,"can_vote":false},{"id":3530840,"name":"Cody B.","username":"Heckboy","avatar_template":"/letter_avatar_proxy/v4/letter/h/da6949/{size}.png","created_at":"2025-02-18T01:02:43.953Z","cooked":"

Have you tried following the videos posted on the YAGSL youtube channel?

The problem with the request is that the configuration is like 90% of a “working YAGSL project”. You would be much better served sharing your code here (as a github repo) and letting us try to help you get it working.

As for testing if the hardware is somehow bad, you can directly control each motor and read values from the encoders/gyro. This is a form of unit testing and is vital to ensuring each component works individually before testing a larger more complex system. If you have REV components, you can use the telemetry tab in the REV Hardware Client to graph values while you manually manipulate each thing and ensure all devices are reporting values back that you expect.

","post_number":3,"post_type":1,"posts_count":16,"updated_at":"2025-02-18T01:13:32.887Z","reply_count":2,"reply_to_post_number":null,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":1,"reads":99,"readers_count":98,"score":49.8,"yours":false,"topic_id":492104,"topic_slug":"in-need-of-working-yagsl-swerve-code","display_username":"Fletch","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":"","bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[{"id":2,"count":1}],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":9105,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":"3181/3015 Mentor | 213/1373 Alum | CSA/FTAA/Jack-of-all-Trades"},"post_url":"/t/in-need-of-working-yagsl-swerve-code/492104/3","custom_user_title":"3181/3015 Mentor | 213/1373 Alum | CSA/FTAA/Jack-of-all-Trades","reactions":[{"id":"heart","type":"emoji","count":1}],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":1,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3530864,"name":"Henry","username":"HawkbotsMentor","avatar_template":"/letter_avatar_proxy/v4/letter/h/d9b06d/{size}.png","created_at":"2025-02-18T01:24:27.233Z","cooked":"

@Heckboy yes, we actually just tried it Saturday. That code is here.

Though that code somewhat worked, our current issue is that the robot sometimes “jumps”. Hold up on the left stick, and it moves in one direction, then will jump in another direction (right or left). It also doesn’t rotate in a stationary circle when we use the right stick…it moves around an imaginary point.

We also aligned all our wheels, checked our encoder offsets, and 3 of them are off, even though we just set them 30 minutes ago. Already literally in the process of switching to CANCoders FYI.

You can see it in our code, but our setup is:

MK4i
Neo
Thrifty Absolute Magnetic Encoders

","post_number":4,"post_type":1,"posts_count":16,"updated_at":"2025-02-18T01:24:27.233Z","reply_count":1,"reply_to_post_number":3,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":2,"reads":90,"readers_count":89,"score":33.0,"yours":false,"topic_id":492104,"topic_slug":"in-need-of-working-yagsl-swerve-code","display_username":"Henry","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"link_counts":[{"url":"https://github.com/OVHSRobotics4619/2025-Code","internal":false,"reflection":false,"title":"GitHub - OVHSRobotics4619/2025-Code","clicks":0}],"read":true,"user_title":null,"reply_to_user":{"id":9105,"username":"Fletch1373","name":"Fletch","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/fletch1373/{size}/220073_2.png"},"bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":68869,"hidden":false,"trust_level":1,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"post_url":"/t/in-need-of-working-yagsl-swerve-code/492104/4","custom_user_title":null,"reactions":[],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":0,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3530869,"name":"Henry","username":"HawkbotsMentor","avatar_template":"/letter_avatar_proxy/v4/letter/h/d9b06d/{size}.png","created_at":"2025-02-18T01:26:42.003Z","cooked":"

P.S. We have tried testing each individual motor (drive and angle) with simple Timed project, with no issues. Didn’t do that with encoders though…

","post_number":5,"post_type":1,"posts_count":16,"updated_at":"2025-02-18T01:26:42.003Z","reply_count":0,"reply_to_post_number":3,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":0,"reads":81,"readers_count":80,"score":16.2,"yours":false,"topic_id":492104,"topic_slug":"in-need-of-working-yagsl-swerve-code","display_username":"Henry","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":null,"reply_to_user":{"id":9105,"username":"Fletch1373","name":"Fletch","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/fletch1373/{size}/220073_2.png"},"bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":68869,"hidden":false,"trust_level":1,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"post_url":"/t/in-need-of-working-yagsl-swerve-code/492104/5","custom_user_title":null,"reactions":[],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":0,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3530891,"name":"Cody B.","username":"Heckboy","avatar_template":"/letter_avatar_proxy/v4/letter/h/da6949/{size}.png","created_at":"2025-02-18T01:45:50.714Z","cooked":"

It looks like you guys just cloned the example code from the YAGSL github. Did you guys try creating a whole a new robot code and following the videos with a fresh slate?

If not, I would recommend trying that. YAGSL is very dependent on your own personal robot. Plug-&-Play only works to a certain extent (and if its working flawlessly, its by pure coincidence)

Also, if your absolute encoder values are jumping around like that, it probably means the magnets aren’t fully glued in. Make the switch to CANCoders like you are doing, and then start fresh following the videos. Don’t clone the example code, just create a new robot code entirely. Copy and paste things you’ve programmed not relating to the swerve drive.

","post_number":6,"post_type":1,"posts_count":16,"updated_at":"2025-02-18T01:45:50.714Z","reply_count":1,"reply_to_post_number":4,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":2,"reads":78,"readers_count":77,"score":30.6,"yours":false,"topic_id":492104,"topic_slug":"in-need-of-working-yagsl-swerve-code","display_username":"Cody B.","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":null,"reply_to_user":{"id":68869,"username":"HawkbotsMentor","name":"Henry","avatar_template":"/letter_avatar_proxy/v4/letter/h/d9b06d/{size}.png"},"bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":50904,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":"M&A-904"},"post_url":"/t/in-need-of-working-yagsl-swerve-code/492104/6","custom_user_title":"M&A-904","reactions":[],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":0,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3530899,"name":"Henry","username":"HawkbotsMentor","avatar_template":"/letter_avatar_proxy/v4/letter/h/d9b06d/{size}.png","created_at":"2025-02-18T01:52:20.995Z","cooked":"

Our coder says yes, we’ve made new code 4 or 5 times. I also just followed along with the YAGSL tutorial video today, and he said that code doesn’t work as well as his example.

Though I’ve personally followed along the YAGSL website, would you recommend also following along in the code? In other words, are there certain sections of the code we are supposed to be deleting, activating, turning on, etc.? I’ve read through a lot of it and didn’t see any instructions in the comments like that, but I admit I haven’t read the example code in full.

","post_number":7,"post_type":1,"posts_count":16,"updated_at":"2025-02-18T01:52:20.995Z","reply_count":2,"reply_to_post_number":6,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":1,"reads":75,"readers_count":74,"score":30.0,"yours":false,"topic_id":492104,"topic_slug":"in-need-of-working-yagsl-swerve-code","display_username":"Henry","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":null,"reply_to_user":{"id":50904,"username":"Heckboy","name":"Cody B.","avatar_template":"/letter_avatar_proxy/v4/letter/h/da6949/{size}.png"},"bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":68869,"hidden":false,"trust_level":1,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"post_url":"/t/in-need-of-working-yagsl-swerve-code/492104/7","custom_user_title":null,"reactions":[],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":0,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3530907,"name":"Eli Barnett","username":"Oblarg","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/oblarg/{size}/161674_2.png","created_at":"2025-02-18T01:58:28.701Z","cooked":"
HawkbotsMentor:

but I admit I haven’t read the example code in full.

Not to put too fine a point on it, but I think this is your primary problem. Before getting a swerve drive to work reliably you typically must read and understand every line of code involved at the user-program level.

This isn’t something you can just follow a step-by-step guide for; it’s a nontrivial systems engineering task. You have to look at telemetry and troubleshoot and figure out why your code is not working in your case. You cannot just bootstrap from someone else’s project; it will likely work no better than the example project you’re trying to use blindly.

","post_number":8,"post_type":1,"posts_count":16,"updated_at":"2025-02-18T01:58:28.701Z","reply_count":1,"reply_to_post_number":7,"quote_count":1,"incoming_link_count":0,"reads":73,"readers_count":72,"score":19.6,"yours":false,"topic_id":492104,"topic_slug":"in-need-of-working-yagsl-swerve-code","display_username":"Eli Barnett","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":"","bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":12381,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":"Robot apartments! invisible suburbs! skeleton treasuries!"},"post_url":"/t/in-need-of-working-yagsl-swerve-code/492104/8","custom_user_title":"Robot apartments! invisible suburbs! skeleton treasuries!","reactions":[],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":0,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3530945,"name":"Henry","username":"HawkbotsMentor","avatar_template":"/letter_avatar_proxy/v4/letter/h/d9b06d/{size}.png","created_at":"2025-02-18T02:30:22.256Z","cooked":"

I haven’t read it in its entirety (though I’ve read a lot), but my coder might have. I’m just trying to support.

So, when you are reading through the code…what did you pay attention to? What had to be changed or understood? Can you cite specific examples from YAGSL so I can understand more?

","post_number":9,"post_type":1,"posts_count":16,"updated_at":"2025-02-18T02:30:22.256Z","reply_count":1,"reply_to_post_number":8,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":0,"reads":58,"readers_count":57,"score":16.6,"yours":false,"topic_id":492104,"topic_slug":"in-need-of-working-yagsl-swerve-code","display_username":"Henry","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":null,"reply_to_user":{"id":12381,"username":"Oblarg","name":"Eli Barnett","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/oblarg/{size}/161674_2.png"},"bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":68869,"hidden":false,"trust_level":1,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"post_url":"/t/in-need-of-working-yagsl-swerve-code/492104/9","custom_user_title":null,"reactions":[],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":0,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3530997,"name":"Eli Barnett","username":"Oblarg","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/oblarg/{size}/161674_2.png","created_at":"2025-02-18T03:00:52.353Z","cooked":"

I can’t really speak for YAGSL in particular, but also the specific library is not the important part. As has been said earlier in the thread, the real challenge is configuring whatever library you’re using to properly reflect your hardware.

This means plotting a whole lot of telemetry and chasing things like unit conversion and sign errors until you know the signal chain is doing what you expect it to be doing.

So, pay attention to your inputs and outputs and find ways to plot them so you can figure out more narrowly what is going wrong. Starting over and hoping it works this time without changing the process won’t work.

","post_number":10,"post_type":1,"posts_count":16,"updated_at":"2025-02-18T03:00:52.353Z","reply_count":0,"reply_to_post_number":9,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":0,"reads":58,"readers_count":57,"score":11.6,"yours":false,"topic_id":492104,"topic_slug":"in-need-of-working-yagsl-swerve-code","display_username":"Eli Barnett","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":"","reply_to_user":{"id":68869,"username":"HawkbotsMentor","name":"Henry","avatar_template":"/letter_avatar_proxy/v4/letter/h/d9b06d/{size}.png"},"bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":12381,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":"Robot apartments! invisible suburbs! skeleton treasuries!"},"post_url":"/t/in-need-of-working-yagsl-swerve-code/492104/10","custom_user_title":"Robot apartments! invisible suburbs! skeleton treasuries!","reactions":[],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":0,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3531062,"name":"Cody B.","username":"Heckboy","avatar_template":"/letter_avatar_proxy/v4/letter/h/da6949/{size}.png","created_at":"2025-02-18T03:18:32.822Z","cooked":"

I don’t mean this to come off the way it might, but I find it hard to believe that the videos were followed. In the github you provided, there is a lot of unnecessary stuff (i.e. the auto balance command from 2023). Along with the presence of configurations for Neos, Falcons, and MaxSwerve. Which tells me, this was cloned from this.

Go into WPILib VS Code for 2025, click the logo in the top right, and create a new project. Select “Template” “Java” “Command Robot”. Give it a name, and your team number. Do not clone from the YAGSL Example Code. Simply follow along with the videos in this playlist

This will get you a driving swerve drive. If you want to get more fancy, use the example code, and the Java API as guidance. Don’t just copy and paste the example code (or pull it from Github). If this does not work, the issue is a mechanical one. From the sounds of it, the encoder magnets are not glued in place very well.

","post_number":11,"post_type":1,"posts_count":16,"updated_at":"2025-02-18T03:18:32.822Z","reply_count":1,"reply_to_post_number":7,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":2,"reads":55,"readers_count":54,"score":41.0,"yours":false,"topic_id":492104,"topic_slug":"in-need-of-working-yagsl-swerve-code","display_username":"Cody B.","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"link_counts":[{"url":"https://youtu.be/4Tcyn_oj_G0?si=FVKu7j4TREqRvD4S","internal":false,"reflection":false,"clicks":7},{"url":"https://github.com/BroncBotz3481/YAGSL-Example/tree/49b8c8f3a350eb53a7ee4f947b5fa77783da0400","internal":false,"reflection":false,"title":"GitHub - BroncBotz3481/YAGSL-Example at 49b8c8f3a350eb53a7ee4f947b5fa77783da0400","clicks":5}],"read":true,"user_title":null,"reply_to_user":{"id":68869,"username":"HawkbotsMentor","name":"Henry","avatar_template":"/letter_avatar_proxy/v4/letter/h/d9b06d/{size}.png"},"bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[{"id":2,"count":1}],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":50904,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":"M&A-904"},"post_url":"/t/in-need-of-working-yagsl-swerve-code/492104/11","custom_user_title":"M&A-904","reactions":[{"id":"heart","type":"emoji","count":1}],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":1,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3531103,"name":"Henry","username":"HawkbotsMentor","avatar_template":"/letter_avatar_proxy/v4/letter/h/d9b06d/{size}.png","created_at":"2025-02-18T03:37:47.577Z","cooked":"

Thanks for the advice! I did follow the video a few hours ago exactly as you said (and to the letter), but it sounds like my coder chose to push his code to Git instead of mine…sorry about that.

CANCoders are almost installed, so we’ll find out if it’s a magnet issue by tomorrow.

","post_number":12,"post_type":1,"posts_count":16,"updated_at":"2025-02-18T03:37:47.577Z","reply_count":0,"reply_to_post_number":11,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":1,"reads":52,"readers_count":51,"score":15.4,"yours":false,"topic_id":492104,"topic_slug":"in-need-of-working-yagsl-swerve-code","display_username":"Henry","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":null,"reply_to_user":{"id":50904,"username":"Heckboy","name":"Cody B.","avatar_template":"/letter_avatar_proxy/v4/letter/h/da6949/{size}.png"},"bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":68869,"hidden":false,"trust_level":1,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"post_url":"/t/in-need-of-working-yagsl-swerve-code/492104/12","custom_user_title":null,"reactions":[],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":0,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3534695,"name":"Henry","username":"HawkbotsMentor","avatar_template":"/letter_avatar_proxy/v4/letter/h/d9b06d/{size}.png","created_at":"2025-02-20T20:46:06.214Z","cooked":"

Update: I used the YAGSL video tutorial through Part 2 to get code (wrote it out last week while following the video), and we replaced our Thrifty encoders with CANCoders. Still could not drive. It’s difficult to explain what the problem is–in fact, that’s why we are having a problem. But I’ll try.

I tried to assess a single issue, so I moved the right joystick left and right to turn the bot. Two wheels (front left and back right) pointed at 45 degree angles in relation to the front of the robot (as expected), and drove correctly. The other 2 wheels were completely off, pointing in a different direction. I would drive the bot around randomly to change the facing of the wheels, then press left/right on the right joystick, and front left and back right would point in the expected direction, but the other two would point in the same wrong direction. This led me to believe it was an encoder offset issue.

So, we found the front right encoder offset (isolating just 1 wheel), put it back into the code (it was different than what was in there already), then drove that wheel around randomly on the carpet. We realigned it as detailed in YAGSL (beveled gear facing left), checked the encoder offset, and the offset was different than the one we had put in. This led us to believe that it is a magnet issue.

We punched out the magnet, and replaced it with a brand new magnet (with loctite 609). Tried again…still had the same offset issue. It seems like the offset is constantly changing for just 2 of the wheels.

Any advice on how to further assess the issue? Or how to solve it?

Not at the computer right now but I’ll post a link to the code tomorrow (it’s not on GitHub yet). I don’t believe it’s a coding issue though since 2 of the wheels act as expected, and the code is copied from the tutorial videos.

HawkbotsMentor:

Any advice on how to further assess the issue? Or how to solve it?

You still have not shared any telemetry plots, and are instead describing macro-level robot behavior.

There’s no way to get a swerve drive working with this approach. You have to do the nitty-gritty systems engineering and trace your signals through your code in a telemetry viewer.

If you don’t know what signals to trace, spend some time reading the implementation (including inside of YAGSL itself) and try to write down a list of places where the signals could be different from what you expect. Then, log the runtime state of your program and see where the program behavior is diverging from your expectation. There are no shortcuts, and there is no alternative route.

To be honest, I don’t think the YAGSL abstraction will serve you well here; you may be better off plumbing up the WPILib classes by hand. Monolithic “do everything in config” libraries tend to make it harder to plot the state you need, because they’re trying to hide it from your user program. Such libraries typically have a skill floor, even if they’re advertised as simplifying the process.
